author: .vbuterin
content: > Eth1 manages just fine with 20 byte addresses; 31 bytes is waaay overkill for the withdrawal commitment.

author: .vbuterin
content: 20 byte addresses are vulnerable to collisions in `2**80` time, and bitcoin does `2**80` hashes every week

author: .vbuterin
content: I think realistically, no serious cryptographic application will be built with an 80 bit security margin this decade

author: .vbuterin
content: And collision attacks on withdrawal commitments do matter! Particularly, if you send money into a stake pool, they could (later) convince you that they can't steal your funds by showing you the opening to the withdrawal commitment that shows that it goes into a contract with known code. But if they have the ability to make two reveals with the same hash, then this guarantee breaks.

author: .vbuterin
content: IMO as part of eth2 we should honestly increase even regular addresses to 29 bytes (the remaining 3 bytes would be 1 for version number + 2 for shard ID, so the package together can still fit into one chunk)

author: .vbuterin
content:
> Why is it ok to lose precision over the generated hash of the public key?

A 32-byte hash with one byte truncated is just a 31-byte hash, which still has 124 bits of collision security (and 29-byte hashes would have 116 bits of collision security)

author: jgm
content: If we do this it leaves addresses without checksums (at the byte level; user representation could still have checksums e.g. bech32), are we okay with this?

author: .vbuterin
content: Why would going up to 32 bytes disallow checksums?

author: .vbuterin
content: Oh I think checksums at the consensus layer are a bad idea
